lead_paragraph: Oklahoma must erase its victories from the 2005 season and will lose two scholarships for the 2008-9 and 2009-10 school years, the N.C.A.A. said yesterday. The penalties stem from a case involving two players, including the Sooners’ starting quarterback, who were kicked off the team in August for being paid for work they had not performed at a Norman, Okla., car dealership. The N.C.A.A. said Oklahoma was guilty of a “failure to monitor” the employment of the players.Oklahoma’s president, David Boren, said the university would appeal the N.C.A.A.’s finding and the ruling that it must erase the victories. Oklahoma has 15 days to notify the N.C.A.A. in writing of an appeal.The Sooners went 8-4 and defeated Oregon in the Holiday Bowl in 2005. Records from that season involving quarterback Rhett Bomar and offensive lineman J. D. Quinn must be erased, the N.C.A.A. said. Last August, just before the Sooners began preseason practice, Coach Bob Stoops dismissed Bomar and Quinn from the team after the university determined they had been paid for work not performed at Big Red Sports and Imports.
